title: No Letup in Bakhmut as Ukraine and Russia Brace for Battles Elsewhere
description: Both sides expect a Ukrainian offensive while the Bakhmut fight continues, but the head of the Wagner mercenary group said Russia must be clearer about its goals.

title: French Anger Shifts From Pension Law to Focus on Macron
description: After ramming through a law raising the retirement age without a full parliamentary vote, the French president faces something approaching a constitutional crisis.

title: Spasms of Violence and ‘Wild Protests’ Jolt Paris
description: Opponents of pension overhaul, mostly young people, hold nightly “wild protests,” marked by vandalism, saying it is the only way to make their voices heard.

title: Senators Urge Biden to Send Evidence of Russian War Crimes to the ICC
description: Despite Pentagon resistance, a bipartisan group stressed that Congress had voted to legalize support for the court’s Ukraine war investigations.

title: Scotland’s Leader Apologizes for Past Practice of Forced Adoptions
description: Nicola Sturgeon said the practice, which was relatively common until the 1970s, was among the gravest injustices in Scottish history.

title: Biden and Trudeau to Meet in Canada for a Summit Meeting
description: A deal on migration and turmoil in Haiti are likely to be two key talking points between the leaders of the neighboring countries.

title: What I’m Reading: The Rise of Fascism Edition
description: A comic novel from the 1930s opens a window on days when what would become a dangerous political movement was seen as a silly hobby.

title: Rwanda Announces Release of Paul Rusesabagina, ‘Hotel Rwanda’ Hero
description: Paul Rusesabagina, whose story inspired a Hollywood movie, was kidnapped by the Rwandan government and jailed. In a deal brokered by the U.S. and Qatar, he is to be set free.

title: Rahul Gandhi, Leader of India’s Opposition to Modi, Expelled From Parliament
description: The expulsion of Rahul Gandhi is a devastating blow to the once-powerful Indian National Congress party. He and several other politicians are now in jeopardy through India’s legal system.

title: Famed Antiwar Protester Was Once Cog in Russia’s Propaganda Machine
description: For 20 years, Marina Ovsyannikova worked for Russian state TV. What compelled her, shortly after Ukraine was invaded, to storm a live broadcast and tell viewers they were being lied to?

title: Russian Force’s Leader Signals No Letup in Bakhmut
description: The founder of Russia’s Wagner private army gave no indication of ending his campaign to seize Bakhmut, while urging the Kremlin to prepare for Ukrainian offensives. Here is what we’re covering:

title: China Denies Pressuring Companies Like TikTok to Spy on Users
description: China’s foreign ministry rebuffed claims made by U.S. lawmakers at a hearing on Thursday that TikTok could be a tool of surveillance for the Chinese government.

title: Israel’s Attorney General Says Netanyahu Broke the Law With Judicial Intervention
description: Gali Baharav-Miara said that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu created a conflict of interest by pushing for a judicial overhaul while on trial for corruption.

title: King Charles Postpones Trip to France Amid Unrest, French Presidency Says
description: France has been rocked by strikes and protests over the past week in response to a move by President Emmanuel Macron to push through an increase in the legal retirement age.

title: Free Speech (or Not) at Stanford
description: A federal judge spoke at Stanford Law School. Chaos ensued.

title: An Australian River Choking on Fish Corpses, and a Community Full of Anger
description: It’s the latest clash over a river basin in New South Wales, Australia, in an arid land where social, economic and environmental interests collide over water issues.

title: Ukraine War Amputees Get New Limbs in U.S.
description: War has forced Ukraine to become skilled at treating amputees, but there are too many for its overtaxed medical workers. Some are finding their way to a prosthetics clinic in Minnesota.

title: A Refuge for Russians and Ukrainians, Bali Rethinks Its Open-Door Policy
description: After multiple accounts of tourists behaving badly, its governor wants Russia and Ukraine to lose access to Indonesia’s visa-on-arrival program.

title: U.S. Due Diligence Firm Says China Detained Its Employees
description: Five Chinese nationals were taken away last Monday, and the company, which does corporate investigations, and its law firm have been unable to contact them.

title: In Held v. Montana, Young People Sue Montana Over Use of Fossil Fuels
description: Sixteen young Montanans have sued their state, arguing that its support of fossil fuels violates the state Constitution.

title: North Korea Says It Tested a Nuclear-Capable Underwater Attack Drone
description: Such a test would be a first for Kim Jong-un’s weapons program. But there was no independent confirmation that it had happened.

title: Melbourne Art and Design, Past and Present
description: Two exhibitions in Melbourne — “Radical Utopia” and “Melbourne Now” — trace the city’s art and design from the 1980s to the present.

title: That Missing Trump Portrait? Found, Next to Some Old Yoga Mats.
description: After a tip, The Times located a portrait of Donald Trump given to him by El Salvador’s president and that Democrats were eager to account for. It was propped up in an obscure spot in a Trump hotel.
